Cristiano Ronaldo reveals terrifying moment gun-wielding police stormed his boat over tax investigation

Cristiano Ronaldo has opened up on the moment his boat was stormed by police.

Spanish tax authorities launched an investigation into the Real Madrid and Portugal star last year, who was accused of evading around £13million.

Ronaldo has been in a legal battle for months and recent reports suggested he had offered to pay around £12m and admit to four courts of tax evasion.

Last summer the 33-year-old was enjoying a break in Formentera, a small island that neighbours Ibiza when police boarded his boat.

"There are thousands of boats in Formentera and police boarded the smallest one, Cristiano Ronaldo's one," he told La Sexta.

"They had guns and cameras. Are we murderers or what? I went up and asked 'what is going on here?'

"It annoyed me but what are you going to do?"

"There are unfair things, but what are you going to do?

"Spain looks after me."

Cristiano Ronaldo makes €14million offer to Spanish tax authorities in bid to avoid prison

Spanish newspaper El Mundo report that Ronaldo has offered to pay €14million (£12.2m) to the taxman and admit to four counts of tax evasion if he avoids prison and if accusations against his advisers, including super-agent Jorge Mendes, are dropped.

The Spanish Treasury have accused Ronaldo of not paying €14.7m (£12.8m) in tax on his image-rights earnings between 2011 and 2014.

Prosecutors have previously said they will push to have Ronaldo pay back the tax and also pay a fine which could reach €100m (£87.3m).
